commits.message:
node: use a linked-list for plugin-conf env vars

Avoid allocating space for 256 env vars in the conf struct
on the stack, when typically just a couple env vars are set.

Technically, using memory in a stack frame that exits for
putenv() was an error, because putenv() uses a reference
to the passed argument (unlike setenv() which copies them).

node: abort if env var key+value exceeds MAX_ENV_BUF_SZ

snprintf() was always used to avoid overflow, but it was never
checked that key_len fits within the buffer
(so there could be an over-read while comparing, and malformed env vars)
use realloc() for env array

Merge pull request #84 from ploxiln/conf_env_ll

* node: use a linked-list for plugin-conf env vars

Avoid allocating space for 256 env vars in the conf struct
on the stack, when typically just a couple env vars are set.

Technically, using memory in a stack frame that exits for
putenv() was an error, because putenv() uses a reference
to the passed argument (unlike setenv() which copies them).

* node: abort if env var key+value exceeds MAX_ENV_BUF_SZ

snprintf() was always used to avoid overflow, but it was never
checked that key_len fits within the buffer
(so there could be an over-read while comparing, and malformed env vars)

* use realloc() for env array instead of the linked-list

issue.title: node: allocate for plugin-conf env vars as needed
issue.body:
Avoid allocating space for 256 env vars in the conf struct on the stack, when typically just a couple env vars are set.

Technically, using memory in a stack frame that exits for putenv() was an error, because putenv() uses a reference to the passed argument (unlike setenv() which copies them).

-----------------

Not really a big deal, 70K on the stack in userspace is totally fine, even for embedded, I think. Just kinda bothered by this big block mostly unused. And then I ran into the `putenv()` referencing thing. Could switch to `setenv()`, just need to split key/value, which can be done in place by just poking a null byte after keylen ...

comment.body: thanks!

This is just a compare - equivalent to `strncmp()` but arguably a little simpler. We know that the new key is key_len and we know that the key in `env->buffer` is also key_len, and after that is a `=` instead of a `\0`. So the `strncmp()` was to stop the compare just before the `=` in the buffer. `strncmp()` would also stop at `\0` but we already know that's past `key_len` anyway, so we can use `memcmp()`. Or I can put it back :)

issue.body:
Avoid allocating space for 256 env vars in the conf struct on the stack, when typically just a couple env vars are set.

Technically, using memory in a stack frame that exits for putenv() was an error, because putenv() uses a reference to the passed argument (unlike setenv() which copies them).

-----------------

Not really a big deal, 70K on the stack in userspace is totally fine, even for embedded, I think. Just kinda bothered by this big block mostly unused. And then I ran into the `putenv()` referencing thing. Could switch to `setenv()`, just need to split key/value, which can be done in place by just poking a null byte after keylen ...

comment.body:
ok, now using realloc ... with a 50% growth factor :)

fwiw here's roughly how I test:

```sh
mkdir -p tmp/{plugins,plugin-conf.d}
vim      tmp/plugins-conf.d/config  # add some random env vars
ln -s ../../src/plugins/munin-plugins-c tmp/plugins/forks
ln -s ../../src/plugins/munin-plugins-c tmp/plugins/load
ln -s $(which env)                      tmp/plugins/env

valgrind --trace-children=yes ./src/node/munin-node-c \
                              -d tmp/plugins -D tmp/plugin-conf.d

# now type "list", "fetch env", etc
```

(and valgrind is how I learned about the behavior of putenv(), which seemed to work fine because that big env array in the exited stack frame wasn't clobbered?)

issue.title: node: use a linked-list for plugin-conf env vars
issue.body:
Avoid allocating space for 256 env vars in the conf struct on the stack, when typically just a couple env vars are set.

Technically, using memory in a stack frame that exits for putenv() was an error, because putenv() uses a reference to the passed argument (unlike setenv() which copies them).

-----------------

Not really a big deal, 70K on the stack in userspace is totally fine, even for embedded, I think. Just kinda bothered by this big block mostly unused. And then I ran into the `putenv()` referencing thing. Could switch to `setenv()`, just need to split key/value, which can be done in place by just poking a null byte after keylen ...

comment.body:
If using `putenv()`, we can't `free()` (until after `execl()` - never), so we need to switch-up things a bit more to use `setenv()` ... we could just call `setenv()` right from `set_value()`, since we only parse the config in the child about to exec the plugin, but that is admittedly a bit weird/unexpected.

These days a linked-list is usually very un-optimal because of cpu caches, and also because of many small allocations, but in this case they're nice because there are typically very few variables so there's very little memory to allocate/touch overall. And if you never need to free (and then allocate other stuff after freeing) there's not much processing overhead.

Anyway, I'll try pushing up an allocation-less style using setenv() (which itself will permanently use memory space somewhere...)

issue.body:
to avoid trying to look up user or group that might not exist
(some distros have "nogroup" instead of "nobody" group)

I was trying to run this on an asuswrt+entware home wifi router, which doesn't have the "nobody" group, and even configuring a different group didn't work because it tried to look up "nogroup" first and aborted.

-----------

Also reduce max number env vars from 256 to 64, since we pre-allocate on the stack for all possible env values, and 256 is overkill.
(yeah this is a bit of a reach, I'd be happy to undo this bit)

pull_request.title: master: get graph width/height for html in graph-cgi mode also
pull_request.body:
When generating html, if graph mode is cron, munin looks for the generated graph png files (from the previous run) to get width and height for the img elements, so that the page doesn't jump around for the few seconds it takes to download all the graph images. This can be done if graph mode is cgi, also, by looking in the cgitmpdir. Sometimes graph images won't be found, but if they are found they can be used.

-----------------

This is admittedly a "hacky" implementation, targeting the last stable branch instead of master. It is offered as an illustration of an idea that would be nice to have, if implemented properly. (The hacky implementation does work!)

If you can recommend a strategy for implementing this "properly" I may attempt it :)

comment.body: When the first lookupd address is added, this `queryLookupd()` is called directly, then the `lookupdLoop()` is spawned to the background. That loop calls this `queryLookupd()` again periodically, while there usually are multiple lookupd addresses, and one of them is queried at a time by this function in a round-robin fashion.

issue.title: fix(consumer): remove old nsqd connections if addresses change
issue.body: Right now, in the event that nsqd addresses change, the old connections stay around in the consumer's connections map. This simply cleans up old connections from that map.

comment.body:
When the connection has some error, including detecting TCP close, it goes through a sequence:
https://github.com/nsqio/go-nsq/blob/master/conn.go#L640
that eventually calls `consumerConnDelegate.OnClose()`:
https://github.com/nsqio/go-nsq/blob/master/conn.go#L725
That calls `Consumer.onConnClose()`:
https://github.com/nsqio/go-nsq/blob/0e8d7a73ef5e81b6c3e2bdc4a9a5fb9afa44a36b/delegates.go#L121

In cases where a server really just switches ip addresses abruptly, there is no TCP FIN or RST that can be sent from the original IP to close the connection, so it'll have to time-out eventually, but operating systems may not enable TCP "keep-alives" by default. But if you do enable them, they should cause the zombie connection to be closed in a few minutes.
https://github.com/golang/go/commit/5bd7e9c54f946eec95d32762e7e9e1222504bfc1
https://tldp.org/HOWTO/TCP-Keepalive-HOWTO/usingkeepalive.html

issue.title: fix(consumer): remove old nsqd connections if addresses change
issue.body: Right now, in the event that nsqd addresses change, the old connections stay around in the consumer's connections map. This simply cleans up old connections from that map.

comment.body:
Normally, connections are removed from `Consumer.connections` in `Consumer.onConnClose()`, which does various other cleanup tasks, to keep things consistent.

Are you having an issue where the tcp connection just hangs and is never detected to be closed?

These successfulNsqdAddrs from a single lookupd. It is expected that the consumer effectively connects to the union of the results from multiple lookupd. Often, all lookupd return the same results, but it is expected that while changes to the set of nsqlookupd propagate there will be inconsistencies, and that's OK because of the "union" behavior. The behavior is also supposed to be resilient to some temporary network disruptions. So we don't really want to remove/disconnect nsqds which are missing from a single lookupd response.

issue.title: nsqadmin: graphite integration not show statsd counter
issue.body:
Hello,

I'm running the nsqadmin with graphite integrated in order to unlock the rate feature. The `depth`, `in-flight`, `deffered`, and `connection `graph are showed up, meanwhile the `messages`, `requested`, timeout, and rate `don't`. 

This is the `docker-compose` file that I use to run nsq and graphite
```yaml
version: '3'
services:
  nsqlookupd:
    image: nsqio/nsq
    container_name: nsqlookupd
    command: /nsqlookupd
    ports:
      - "4160:4160"
      - "4161:4161"
  nsqd:
    image: nsqio/nsq
    container_name: nsqd
    command: /nsqd --broadcast-address=nsqd --statsd-address=graphite:8125 --data-path=/data --lookupd-tcp-address=nsqlookupd:4160 --statsd-interval=0m45s
    volumes:
      - /data
    depends_on:
      - nsqlookupd
      - graphite
    ports:
      - "4150:4150"
      - "4151:4151"
  nsqadmin:
    image: nsqio/nsq
    container_name: nsqadmin
    command: /nsqadmin --lookupd-http-address=nsqlookupd:4161 --proxy-graphite=true --graphite-url=http://graphite --statsd-interval=0m45s 
    depends_on:
      - nsqlookupd
      - nsqd
      - graphite
    ports:
      - "4171:4171"
  graphite:
    image: graphiteapp/graphite-statsd:1.1.10-3
    container_name: graphite
    ports:
      - 80:80
      - 2003-2004:2003-2004
      - 2023-2024:2023-2024
      - 8125:8125/udp
      - 8126:8126
```

Here is the full picture from nsqadmin.

![Screenshot 2022-10-29 105804](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64145699/198812810-69d810f8-f1ea-4fcc-ab61-8e918094666a.png)

Moreover, I also added the additional configuration for graphite as mentioned here [https://nsq.io/components/nsqd.html#statsd--graphite-integration](https://nsq.io/components/nsqd.html#statsd--graphite-integration). Here is the screenshot taken from graphite container for additional config on `storage-schemas.conf` and `storage-aggregation.conf` files.

![Screenshot 2022-10-29 110250](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64145699/198812998-8f001412-474d-4a0f-8df4-762ab10d2259.png)

![Screenshot 2022-10-29 110230](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64145699/198813001-d6f0f625-4cd3-439c-a6fe-482700dc09cc.png)

Here is the screenshot taken from graphite browser. The `gauge` folder showed up, meanwhile the `counter` folder doesn't.

![Screenshot 2022-10-29 110425](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64145699/198813060-a77392e3-4754-4ef9-b3f5-26d88ed093b1.png)

Is there any configuration that I missed so that the `rate` etc doesn't show up in the nsqadmin?

Thank you for the assists!

comment.body:
nsqadmin gets the data from graphite, it's in there somewhere. If you click on the graphs in nsqadmin you can see the (url-encoded) graphite expression in the URL. (btw I typically use the graphite "Dashboard" instead of the "Composer", but not everyone likes it, most like setting up graphana as the UI for graphite ... but they all take some figuring out.)

As for why the rate doesn't seem to work for you, sorry I don't know. It's also a graphite expression, you could inspect in the network tab of the browser debugger.

issue.title: Can we consume a new topic after nsq fully running?
issue.body: We have a use case to publish a message to a topic dynamically, but we want to make sure the consumer will be consuming to the new topic too, is it possible to do so?

comment.body:
The usual consumer libraries do not have options to discover new topics, you typically configure which topic to consume.

I suppose you could write custom code to periodically poll nsqlookupd (via http api) for all available topics, check for new ones matching a pattern, and create new consumer instances for them, whether in the same process, or as subprocesses, or services managed by another system ...

... but this is generally not how nsq is designed to be used. Generally topics are more pre-planned and "fat". So you wouldn't create a new topic for every regular user that signs up, instead you'd have a user-events or user-actions topic that would be used for all users, and consumers can quickly filter-out many messages that are not relevant to them.

comment.body: This probably has to do with the behavior of statsd specifically ... I haven't set this up in a while, so the details escape me, but I think the issue is that the original statsd added the "gauges" / "counters" / "timers" prefixes to the metric name, while the statsd that nsq was usually used with did not: https://github.com/bitly/statsdaemon (it made more sense to us to organize stats by subject rather than by type). _nsqadmin_ has `--statsd-gauge-format` and `--statsd-counter-format` flags/options to adapt for this, and it looks like the defaults are intended for the original statsd, but it was less tested so there's probably an inconsistency in there somewhere. As you note, gauges are in their own folder, but counters are not? Maybe by changing _nsqadmin_ `--statsd-counter-format` you can adjust for it?

issue.title: channel: prevent infinite loop sending to closed channel
issue.body:
Both sendall and sendall_stderr call send inside a loop and use its result to advance their buffer. If the channel is closed, send returns 0 which causes both sendall methods to go into an infinite loop. Prevent this from occurring by using the open_only decorator.

I'm not sure this is the best fix since I haven't verified whether the channel can be closed after the sending begins. If so, then both sendall routines should instead raise an exception if send returns 0.

comment.body:
I'm unsure of this particular solution, because:

 * `@open_only` checks for both `eof_sent` and `eof_received`. stdin and stdout are independent. These send methods should probably only check eof_sent?
 * These methods call `send()` which calls `_send()`, which raises an exception if the socket is closed (another thing `@open_only` checks). But it does seem that `_send()` can just return `0` if `eof_sent`, maybe just that should be checked.
 * Maybe the check should be inside the `while` loop in these send_all methods, instead of on the outside, in case the EOF occurs after starting the method?

issue.title: nsqd: optimize the performance of httpServer's doPub
issue.body:
When a dense request is encountered and a single message is large, the use of ioutil.ReadAll will have an impact on the performance,  causing a certain degree of memory leak. I have encountered serious cases, resulting in OOM. Because ioutil.ReadAll is to read out the information at one time. A large amount of information will also cause the expansion of the slice and affect the performance. At the same time, it will cause memory escape and increase the burden of GC.

Using io.Copy() avoids reading out messages at one time, and using pool improves memory utilization and reduce the burden of GC.

comment.body: hmm I'm skeptical of how `io.Copy()` into a new `bytes.Buffer{}` without pre-allocated size could be better. I think that this benchmark may not be representative of a real workload because the copied messages can be garbage-collected immediately, whereas in nsqd they need to live on for an indeterminate amount of time and be accessed by other goroutines. (we can't see the implementation of `handleBytes()` ...)

commits.message:
node: use a linked-list for plugin-conf env vars

Avoid allocating space for 256 env vars in the conf struct
on the stack, when typically just a couple env vars are set.

Technically, using memory in a stack frame that exits for
putenv() was an error, because putenv() uses a reference
to the passed argument (unlike setenv() which copies them).

node: abort if env var key+value exceeds MAX_ENV_BUF_SZ

snprintf() was always used to avoid overflow, but it was never
checked that key_len fits within the buffer
(so there could be an over-read while comparing, and malformed env vars)
use realloc() for env array

Merge pull request #84 from ploxiln/conf_env_ll

* node: use a linked-list for plugin-conf env vars

Avoid allocating space for 256 env vars in the conf struct
on the stack, when typically just a couple env vars are set.

Technically, using memory in a stack frame that exits for
putenv() was an error, because putenv() uses a reference
to the passed argument (unlike setenv() which copies them).

* node: abort if env var key+value exceeds MAX_ENV_BUF_SZ

snprintf() was always used to avoid overflow, but it was never
checked that key_len fits within the buffer
(so there could be an over-read while comparing, and malformed env vars)

* use realloc() for env array instead of the linked-list

issue.title: node: allocate for plugin-conf env vars as needed
issue.body:
Avoid allocating space for 256 env vars in the conf struct on the stack, when typically just a couple env vars are set.

Technically, using memory in a stack frame that exits for putenv() was an error, because putenv() uses a reference to the passed argument (unlike setenv() which copies them).

-----------------

Not really a big deal, 70K on the stack in userspace is totally fine, even for embedded, I think. Just kinda bothered by this big block mostly unused. And then I ran into the `putenv()` referencing thing. Could switch to `setenv()`, just need to split key/value, which can be done in place by just poking a null byte after keylen ...

comment.body: thanks!

This is just a compare - equivalent to `strncmp()` but arguably a little simpler. We know that the new key is key_len and we know that the key in `env->buffer` is also key_len, and after that is a `=` instead of a `\0`. So the `strncmp()` was to stop the compare just before the `=` in the buffer. `strncmp()` would also stop at `\0` but we already know that's past `key_len` anyway, so we can use `memcmp()`. Or I can put it back :)

comment.body:
ok, now using realloc ... with a 50% growth factor :)

fwiw here's roughly how I test:

```sh
mkdir -p tmp/{plugins,plugin-conf.d}
vim      tmp/plugins-conf.d/config  # add some random env vars
ln -s ../../src/plugins/munin-plugins-c tmp/plugins/forks
ln -s ../../src/plugins/munin-plugins-c tmp/plugins/load
ln -s $(which env)                      tmp/plugins/env

valgrind --trace-children=yes ./src/node/munin-node-c \
                              -d tmp/plugins -D tmp/plugin-conf.d

# now type "list", "fetch env", etc
```

(and valgrind is how I learned about the behavior of putenv(), which seemed to work fine because that big env array in the exited stack frame wasn't clobbered?)

issue.title: node: use a linked-list for plugin-conf env vars
issue.body:
Avoid allocating space for 256 env vars in the conf struct on the stack, when typically just a couple env vars are set.

Technically, using memory in a stack frame that exits for putenv() was an error, because putenv() uses a reference to the passed argument (unlike setenv() which copies them).

-----------------

Not really a big deal, 70K on the stack in userspace is totally fine, even for embedded, I think. Just kinda bothered by this big block mostly unused. And then I ran into the `putenv()` referencing thing. Could switch to `setenv()`, just need to split key/value, which can be done in place by just poking a null byte after keylen ...

comment.body:
If using `putenv()`, we can't `free()` (until after `execl()` - never), so we need to switch-up things a bit more to use `setenv()` ... we could just call `setenv()` right from `set_value()`, since we only parse the config in the child about to exec the plugin, but that is admittedly a bit weird/unexpected.

These days a linked-list is usually very un-optimal because of cpu caches, and also because of many small allocations, but in this case they're nice because there are typically very few variables so there's very little memory to allocate/touch overall. And if you never need to free (and then allocate other stuff after freeing) there's not much processing overhead.

Anyway, I'll try pushing up an allocation-less style using setenv() (which itself will permanently use memory space somewhere...)

 * add blank lines between steps for readability

pull_request.title: master: get graph width/height for html in graph-cgi mode also
pull_request.body:
When generating html, if graph mode is cron, munin looks for the generated graph png files (from the previous run) to get width and height for the img elements, so that the page doesn't jump around for the few seconds it takes to download all the graph images. This can be done if graph mode is cgi, also, by looking in the cgitmpdir. Sometimes graph images won't be found, but if they are found they can be used.

-----------------

This is admittedly a "hacky" implementation, targeting the last stable branch instead of master. It is offered as an illustration of an idea that would be nice to have, if implemented properly. (The hacky implementation does work!)

If you can recommend a strategy for implementing this "properly" I may attempt it :)

comment.body: When the first lookupd address is added, this `queryLookupd()` is called directly, then the `lookupdLoop()` is spawned to the background. That loop calls this `queryLookupd()` again periodically, while there usually are multiple lookupd addresses, and one of them is queried at a time by this function in a round-robin fashion.

issue.title: fix(consumer): remove old nsqd connections if addresses change
issue.body: Right now, in the event that nsqd addresses change, the old connections stay around in the consumer's connections map. This simply cleans up old connections from that map.

comment.body:
When the connection has some error, including detecting TCP close, it goes through a sequence:
https://github.com/nsqio/go-nsq/blob/master/conn.go#L640
that eventually calls `consumerConnDelegate.OnClose()`:
https://github.com/nsqio/go-nsq/blob/master/conn.go#L725
That calls `Consumer.onConnClose()`:
https://github.com/nsqio/go-nsq/blob/0e8d7a73ef5e81b6c3e2bdc4a9a5fb9afa44a36b/delegates.go#L121

In cases where a server really just switches ip addresses abruptly, there is no TCP FIN or RST that can be sent from the original IP to close the connection, so it'll have to time-out eventually, but operating systems may not enable TCP "keep-alives" by default. But if you do enable them, they should cause the zombie connection to be closed in a few minutes.
https://github.com/golang/go/commit/5bd7e9c54f946eec95d32762e7e9e1222504bfc1
https://tldp.org/HOWTO/TCP-Keepalive-HOWTO/usingkeepalive.html

issue.title: fix(consumer): remove old nsqd connections if addresses change
issue.body: Right now, in the event that nsqd addresses change, the old connections stay around in the consumer's connections map. This simply cleans up old connections from that map.

comment.body:
Normally, connections are removed from `Consumer.connections` in `Consumer.onConnClose()`, which does various other cleanup tasks, to keep things consistent.

Are you having an issue where the tcp connection just hangs and is never detected to be closed?

These successfulNsqdAddrs from a single lookupd. It is expected that the consumer effectively connects to the union of the results from multiple lookupd. Often, all lookupd return the same results, but it is expected that while changes to the set of nsqlookupd propagate there will be inconsistencies, and that's OK because of the "union" behavior. The behavior is also supposed to be resilient to some temporary network disruptions. So we don't really want to remove/disconnect nsqds which are missing from a single lookupd response.

issue.title: nsqadmin: graphite integration not show statsd counter
issue.body:
Hello,

I'm running the nsqadmin with graphite integrated in order to unlock the rate feature. The `depth`, `in-flight`, `deffered`, and `connection `graph are showed up, meanwhile the `messages`, `requested`, timeout, and rate `don't`. 

This is the `docker-compose` file that I use to run nsq and graphite
```yaml
version: '3'
services:
  nsqlookupd:
    image: nsqio/nsq
    container_name: nsqlookupd
    command: /nsqlookupd
    ports:
      - "4160:4160"
      - "4161:4161"
  nsqd:
    image: nsqio/nsq
    container_name: nsqd
    command: /nsqd --broadcast-address=nsqd --statsd-address=graphite:8125 --data-path=/data --lookupd-tcp-address=nsqlookupd:4160 --statsd-interval=0m45s
    volumes:
      - /data
    depends_on:
      - nsqlookupd
      - graphite
    ports:
      - "4150:4150"
      - "4151:4151"
  nsqadmin:
    image: nsqio/nsq
    container_name: nsqadmin
    command: /nsqadmin --lookupd-http-address=nsqlookupd:4161 --proxy-graphite=true --graphite-url=http://graphite --statsd-interval=0m45s 
    depends_on:
      - nsqlookupd
      - nsqd
      - graphite
    ports:
      - "4171:4171"
  graphite:
    image: graphiteapp/graphite-statsd:1.1.10-3
    container_name: graphite
    ports:
      - 80:80
      - 2003-2004:2003-2004
      - 2023-2024:2023-2024
      - 8125:8125/udp
      - 8126:8126
```

Here is the full picture from nsqadmin.

![Screenshot 2022-10-29 105804](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64145699/198812810-69d810f8-f1ea-4fcc-ab61-8e918094666a.png)

Moreover, I also added the additional configuration for graphite as mentioned here [https://nsq.io/components/nsqd.html#statsd--graphite-integration](https://nsq.io/components/nsqd.html#statsd--graphite-integration). Here is the screenshot taken from graphite container for additional config on `storage-schemas.conf` and `storage-aggregation.conf` files.

![Screenshot 2022-10-29 110250](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64145699/198812998-8f001412-474d-4a0f-8df4-762ab10d2259.png)

![Screenshot 2022-10-29 110230](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64145699/198813001-d6f0f625-4cd3-439c-a6fe-482700dc09cc.png)

Here is the screenshot taken from graphite browser. The `gauge` folder showed up, meanwhile the `counter` folder doesn't.

![Screenshot 2022-10-29 110425](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64145699/198813060-a77392e3-4754-4ef9-b3f5-26d88ed093b1.png)

Is there any configuration that I missed so that the `rate` etc doesn't show up in the nsqadmin?

Thank you for the assists!

comment.body:
nsqadmin gets the data from graphite, it's in there somewhere. If you click on the graphs in nsqadmin you can see the (url-encoded) graphite expression in the URL. (btw I typically use the graphite "Dashboard" instead of the "Composer", but not everyone likes it, most like setting up graphana as the UI for graphite ... but they all take some figuring out.)

As for why the rate doesn't seem to work for you, sorry I don't know. It's also a graphite expression, you could inspect in the network tab of the browser debugger.

issue.title: Can we consume a new topic after nsq fully running?
issue.body: We have a use case to publish a message to a topic dynamically, but we want to make sure the consumer will be consuming to the new topic too, is it possible to do so?

comment.body:
The usual consumer libraries do not have options to discover new topics, you typically configure which topic to consume.

I suppose you could write custom code to periodically poll nsqlookupd (via http api) for all available topics, check for new ones matching a pattern, and create new consumer instances for them, whether in the same process, or as subprocesses, or services managed by another system ...

... but this is generally not how nsq is designed to be used. Generally topics are more pre-planned and "fat". So you wouldn't create a new topic for every regular user that signs up, instead you'd have a user-events or user-actions topic that would be used for all users, and consumers can quickly filter-out many messages that are not relevant to them.

comment.body: This probably has to do with the behavior of statsd specifically ... I haven't set this up in a while, so the details escape me, but I think the issue is that the original statsd added the "gauges" / "counters" / "timers" prefixes to the metric name, while the statsd that nsq was usually used with did not: https://github.com/bitly/statsdaemon (it made more sense to us to organize stats by subject rather than by type). _nsqadmin_ has `--statsd-gauge-format` and `--statsd-counter-format` flags/options to adapt for this, and it looks like the defaults are intended for the original statsd, but it was less tested so there's probably an inconsistency in there somewhere. As you note, gauges are in their own folder, but counters are not? Maybe by changing _nsqadmin_ `--statsd-counter-format` you can adjust for it?

issue.title: channel: prevent infinite loop sending to closed channel
issue.body:
Both sendall and sendall_stderr call send inside a loop and use its result to advance their buffer. If the channel is closed, send returns 0 which causes both sendall methods to go into an infinite loop. Prevent this from occurring by using the open_only decorator.

I'm not sure this is the best fix since I haven't verified whether the channel can be closed after the sending begins. If so, then both sendall routines should instead raise an exception if send returns 0.

comment.body:
I'm unsure of this particular solution, because:

 * `@open_only` checks for both `eof_sent` and `eof_received`. stdin and stdout are independent. These send methods should probably only check eof_sent?
 * These methods call `send()` which calls `_send()`, which raises an exception if the socket is closed (another thing `@open_only` checks). But it does seem that `_send()` can just return `0` if `eof_sent`, maybe just that should be checked.
 * Maybe the check should be inside the `while` loop in these send_all methods, instead of on the outside, in case the EOF occurs after starting the method?

issue.title: nsqd: optimize the performance of httpServer's doPub
issue.body:
When a dense request is encountered and a single message is large, the use of ioutil.ReadAll will have an impact on the performance,  causing a certain degree of memory leak. I have encountered serious cases, resulting in OOM. Because ioutil.ReadAll is to read out the information at one time. A large amount of information will also cause the expansion of the slice and affect the performance. At the same time, it will cause memory escape and increase the burden of GC.

Using io.Copy() avoids reading out messages at one time, and using pool improves memory utilization and reduce the burden of GC.

comment.body: hmm I'm skeptical of how `io.Copy()` into a new `bytes.Buffer{}` without pre-allocated size could be better. I think that this benchmark may not be representative of a real workload because the copied messages can be garbage-collected immediately, whereas in nsqd they need to live on for an indeterminate amount of time and be accessed by other goroutines. (we can't see the implementation of `handleBytes()` ...)

commits.message:
node: use a linked-list for plugin-conf env vars

Avoid allocating space for 256 env vars in the conf struct
on the stack, when typically just a couple env vars are set.

Technically, using memory in a stack frame that exits for
putenv() was an error, because putenv() uses a reference
to the passed argument (unlike setenv() which copies them).

node: abort if env var key+value exceeds MAX_ENV_BUF_SZ

snprintf() was always used to avoid overflow, but it was never
checked that key_len fits within the buffer
(so there could be an over-read while comparing, and malformed env vars)
use realloc() for env array

Merge pull request #84 from ploxiln/conf_env_ll

* node: abort if env var key+value exceeds MAX_ENV_BUF_SZ

issue.title: node: allocate for plugin-conf env vars as needed
issue.body:
Avoid allocating space for 256 env vars in the conf struct on the stack, when typically just a couple env vars are set.

Technically, using memory in a stack frame that exits for putenv() was an error, because putenv() uses a reference to the passed argument (unlike setenv() which copies them).

-----------------

Not really a big deal, 70K on the stack in userspace is totally fine, even for embedded, I think. Just kinda bothered by this big block mostly unused. And then I ran into the `putenv()` referencing thing. Could switch to `setenv()`, just need to split key/value, which can be done in place by just poking a null byte after keylen ...

comment.body: thanks!

This is just a compare - equivalent to `strncmp()` but arguably a little simpler. We know that the new key is key_len and we know that the key in `env->buffer` is also key_len, and after that is a `=` instead of a `\0`. So the `strncmp()` was to stop the compare just before the `=` in the buffer. `strncmp()` would also stop at `\0` but we already know that's past `key_len` anyway, so we can use `memcmp()`. Or I can put it back :)

Technically, using memory in a stack frame that exits for putenv() was an error, because putenv() uses a reference to the passed argument (unlike setenv() which copies them).

-----------------

Not really a big deal, 70K on the stack in userspace is totally fine, even for embedded, I think. Just kinda bothered by this big block mostly unused. And then I ran into the `putenv()` referencing thing. Could switch to `setenv()`, just need to split key/value, which can be done in place by just poking a null byte after keylen ...

comment.body:
ok, now using realloc ... with a 50% growth factor :)

fwiw here's roughly how I test:

```sh
mkdir -p tmp/{plugins,plugin-conf.d}
vim      tmp/plugins-conf.d/config  # add some random env vars
ln -s ../../src/plugins/munin-plugins-c tmp/plugins/forks
ln -s ../../src/plugins/munin-plugins-c tmp/plugins/load
ln -s $(which env)                      tmp/plugins/env

valgrind --trace-children=yes ./src/node/munin-node-c \
                              -d tmp/plugins -D tmp/plugin-conf.d

# now type "list", "fetch env", etc
```

(and valgrind is how I learned about the behavior of putenv(), which seemed to work fine because that big env array in the exited stack frame wasn't clobbered?)

issue.title: node: use a linked-list for plugin-conf env vars
issue.body:
Avoid allocating space for 256 env vars in the conf struct on the stack, when typically just a couple env vars are set.

Technically, using memory in a stack frame that exits for putenv() was an error, because putenv() uses a reference to the passed argument (unlike setenv() which copies them).

-----------------

Not really a big deal, 70K on the stack in userspace is totally fine, even for embedded, I think. Just kinda bothered by this big block mostly unused. And then I ran into the `putenv()` referencing thing. Could switch to `setenv()`, just need to split key/value, which can be done in place by just poking a null byte after keylen ...

comment.body:
If using `putenv()`, we can't `free()` (until after `execl()` - never), so we need to switch-up things a bit more to use `setenv()` ... we could just call `setenv()` right from `set_value()`, since we only parse the config in the child about to exec the plugin, but that is admittedly a bit weird/unexpected.

These days a linked-list is usually very un-optimal because of cpu caches, and also because of many small allocations, but in this case they're nice because there are typically very few variables so there's very little memory to allocate/touch overall. And if you never need to free (and then allocate other stuff after freeing) there's not much processing overhead.

Anyway, I'll try pushing up an allocation-less style using setenv() (which itself will permanently use memory space somewhere...)

issue.title: node: lookup user and group after parsing plugin conf
issue.body:
to avoid trying to look up user or group that might not exist
(some distros have "nogroup" instead of "nobody" group)

I was trying to run this on an asuswrt+entware home wifi router, which doesn't have the "nobody" group, and even configuring a different group didn't work because it tried to look up "nogroup" first and aborted.

-----------

Also reduce max number env vars from 256 to 64, since we pre-allocate on the stack for all possible env values, and 256 is overkill.
(yeah this is a bit of a reach, I'd be happy to undo this bit)

pull_request.title: master: get graph width/height for html in graph-cgi mode also
pull_request.body:
When generating html, if graph mode is cron, munin looks for the generated graph png files (from the previous run) to get width and height for the img elements, so that the page doesn't jump around for the few seconds it takes to download all the graph images. This can be done if graph mode is cgi, also, by looking in the cgitmpdir. Sometimes graph images won't be found, but if they are found they can be used.

-----------------

This is admittedly a "hacky" implementation, targeting the last stable branch instead of master. It is offered as an illustration of an idea that would be nice to have, if implemented properly. (The hacky implementation does work!)

If you can recommend a strategy for implementing this "properly" I may attempt it :)

issue.title: fix(consumer): remove old nsqd connections if addresses change
issue.body: Right now, in the event that nsqd addresses change, the old connections stay around in the consumer's connections map. This simply cleans up old connections from that map.

comment.body:
When the connection has some error, including detecting TCP close, it goes through a sequence:
https://github.com/nsqio/go-nsq/blob/master/conn.go#L640
that eventually calls `consumerConnDelegate.OnClose()`:
https://github.com/nsqio/go-nsq/blob/master/conn.go#L725
That calls `Consumer.onConnClose()`:
https://github.com/nsqio/go-nsq/blob/0e8d7a73ef5e81b6c3e2bdc4a9a5fb9afa44a36b/delegates.go#L121

In cases where a server really just switches ip addresses abruptly, there is no TCP FIN or RST that can be sent from the original IP to close the connection, so it'll have to time-out eventually, but operating systems may not enable TCP "keep-alives" by default. But if you do enable them, they should cause the zombie connection to be closed in a few minutes.
https://github.com/golang/go/commit/5bd7e9c54f946eec95d32762e7e9e1222504bfc1
https://tldp.org/HOWTO/TCP-Keepalive-HOWTO/usingkeepalive.html

issue.title: fix(consumer): remove old nsqd connections if addresses change
issue.body: Right now, in the event that nsqd addresses change, the old connections stay around in the consumer's connections map. This simply cleans up old connections from that map.

comment.body:
Normally, connections are removed from `Consumer.connections` in `Consumer.onConnClose()`, which does various other cleanup tasks, to keep things consistent.

Are you having an issue where the tcp connection just hangs and is never detected to be closed?

These successfulNsqdAddrs from a single lookupd. It is expected that the consumer effectively connects to the union of the results from multiple lookupd. Often, all lookupd return the same results, but it is expected that while changes to the set of nsqlookupd propagate there will be inconsistencies, and that's OK because of the "union" behavior. The behavior is also supposed to be resilient to some temporary network disruptions. So we don't really want to remove/disconnect nsqds which are missing from a single lookupd response.

issue.title: nsqadmin: graphite integration not show statsd counter
issue.body:
Hello,

I'm running the nsqadmin with graphite integrated in order to unlock the rate feature. The `depth`, `in-flight`, `deffered`, and `connection `graph are showed up, meanwhile the `messages`, `requested`, timeout, and rate `don't`. 

This is the `docker-compose` file that I use to run nsq and graphite
```yaml
version: '3'
services:
  nsqlookupd:
    image: nsqio/nsq
    container_name: nsqlookupd
    command: /nsqlookupd
    ports:
      - "4160:4160"
      - "4161:4161"
  nsqd:
    image: nsqio/nsq
    container_name: nsqd
    command: /nsqd --broadcast-address=nsqd --statsd-address=graphite:8125 --data-path=/data --lookupd-tcp-address=nsqlookupd:4160 --statsd-interval=0m45s
    volumes:
      - /data
    depends_on:
      - nsqlookupd
      - graphite
    ports:
      - "4150:4150"
      - "4151:4151"
  nsqadmin:
    image: nsqio/nsq
    container_name: nsqadmin
    command: /nsqadmin --lookupd-http-address=nsqlookupd:4161 --proxy-graphite=true --graphite-url=http://graphite --statsd-interval=0m45s 
    depends_on:
      - nsqlookupd
      - nsqd
      - graphite
    ports:
      - "4171:4171"
  graphite:
    image: graphiteapp/graphite-statsd:1.1.10-3
    container_name: graphite
    ports:
      - 80:80
      - 2003-2004:2003-2004
      - 2023-2024:2023-2024
      - 8125:8125/udp
      - 8126:8126
```

Here is the full picture from nsqadmin.

![Screenshot 2022-10-29 105804](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64145699/198812810-69d810f8-f1ea-4fcc-ab61-8e918094666a.png)

Moreover, I also added the additional configuration for graphite as mentioned here [https://nsq.io/components/nsqd.html#statsd--graphite-integration](https://nsq.io/components/nsqd.html#statsd--graphite-integration). Here is the screenshot taken from graphite container for additional config on `storage-schemas.conf` and `storage-aggregation.conf` files.

![Screenshot 2022-10-29 110250](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64145699/198812998-8f001412-474d-4a0f-8df4-762ab10d2259.png)

![Screenshot 2022-10-29 110230](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64145699/198813001-d6f0f625-4cd3-439c-a6fe-482700dc09cc.png)

Here is the screenshot taken from graphite browser. The `gauge` folder showed up, meanwhile the `counter` folder doesn't.

![Screenshot 2022-10-29 110425](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64145699/198813060-a77392e3-4754-4ef9-b3f5-26d88ed093b1.png)

Is there any configuration that I missed so that the `rate` etc doesn't show up in the nsqadmin?

Thank you for the assists!

comment.body:
nsqadmin gets the data from graphite, it's in there somewhere. If you click on the graphs in nsqadmin you can see the (url-encoded) graphite expression in the URL. (btw I typically use the graphite "Dashboard" instead of the "Composer", but not everyone likes it, most like setting up graphana as the UI for graphite ... but they all take some figuring out.)

As for why the rate doesn't seem to work for you, sorry I don't know. It's also a graphite expression, you could inspect in the network tab of the browser debugger.

issue.title: Can we consume a new topic after nsq fully running?
issue.body: We have a use case to publish a message to a topic dynamically, but we want to make sure the consumer will be consuming to the new topic too, is it possible to do so?

comment.body:
The usual consumer libraries do not have options to discover new topics, you typically configure which topic to consume.

I suppose you could write custom code to periodically poll nsqlookupd (via http api) for all available topics, check for new ones matching a pattern, and create new consumer instances for them, whether in the same process, or as subprocesses, or services managed by another system ...

... but this is generally not how nsq is designed to be used. Generally topics are more pre-planned and "fat". So you wouldn't create a new topic for every regular user that signs up, instead you'd have a user-events or user-actions topic that would be used for all users, and consumers can quickly filter-out many messages that are not relevant to them.

comment.body: This probably has to do with the behavior of statsd specifically ... I haven't set this up in a while, so the details escape me, but I think the issue is that the original statsd added the "gauges" / "counters" / "timers" prefixes to the metric name, while the statsd that nsq was usually used with did not: https://github.com/bitly/statsdaemon (it made more sense to us to organize stats by subject rather than by type). _nsqadmin_ has `--statsd-gauge-format` and `--statsd-counter-format` flags/options to adapt for this, and it looks like the defaults are intended for the original statsd, but it was less tested so there's probably an inconsistency in there somewhere. As you note, gauges are in their own folder, but counters are not? Maybe by changing _nsqadmin_ `--statsd-counter-format` you can adjust for it?

issue.title: channel: prevent infinite loop sending to closed channel
issue.body:
Both sendall and sendall_stderr call send inside a loop and use its result to advance their buffer. If the channel is closed, send returns 0 which causes both sendall methods to go into an infinite loop. Prevent this from occurring by using the open_only decorator.

I'm not sure this is the best fix since I haven't verified whether the channel can be closed after the sending begins. If so, then both sendall routines should instead raise an exception if send returns 0.

comment.body:
I'm unsure of this particular solution, because:

 * `@open_only` checks for both `eof_sent` and `eof_received`. stdin and stdout are independent. These send methods should probably only check eof_sent?
 * These methods call `send()` which calls `_send()`, which raises an exception if the socket is closed (another thing `@open_only` checks). But it does seem that `_send()` can just return `0` if `eof_sent`, maybe just that should be checked.
 * Maybe the check should be inside the `while` loop in these send_all methods, instead of on the outside, in case the EOF occurs after starting the method?

issue.title: nsqd: optimize the performance of httpServer's doPub
issue.body:
When a dense request is encountered and a single message is large, the use of ioutil.ReadAll will have an impact on the performance,  causing a certain degree of memory leak. I have encountered serious cases, resulting in OOM. Because ioutil.ReadAll is to read out the information at one time. A large amount of information will also cause the expansion of the slice and affect the performance. At the same time, it will cause memory escape and increase the burden of GC.

Using io.Copy() avoids reading out messages at one time, and using pool improves memory utilization and reduce the burden of GC.

comment.body: hmm I'm skeptical of how `io.Copy()` into a new `bytes.Buffer{}` without pre-allocated size could be better. I think that this benchmark may not be representative of a real workload because the copied messages can be garbage-collected immediately, whereas in nsqd they need to live on for an indeterminate amount of time and be accessed by other goroutines. (we can't see the implementation of `handleBytes()` ...)
